Situation1: They openly turn to each other for help in a difficult personal moment.
Expectation2: Be friendly and polite in daily interactions
Situation2: A noise complaint has circulated on the floor, and a face-to-face meeting in the lobby calls for extra courtesy.
Story: I was halfway through comforting my younger brother on the phone, his voice shaky as he confided in me about his breakup, when I heard the elevator doors open. I glanced up and saw Mrs. Patel, my neighbor from across the hall, walking toward me with a tight smile. I knew why—there had been a noise complaint about our apartment, and I could feel the tension in the air. As a sister, I wanted nothing more than to stay on the line, to reassure my brother that I was there for him, that he could lean on me. But as a neighbor, I was expected to be polite, to address the complaint with understanding and friendliness, to not let personal matters spill into our shared space. My brother’s voice trembled in my ear, asking if I was still there, while Mrs. Patel waited expectantly, her eyes kind but firm. I felt pulled in two directions, my heart pounding as I tried to figure out how to be the sister he needed and the neighbor she expected—all at the same time.
